subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 1040
msgSnippet: ... You could probably do this if you wrote a custom TestRunner. If you know Aspect-Oriented Programming, this also seems like a good use for it. It would be
messageBody:
Nathan Coast wrote:
> Hi,
>
> Is anyone doing performance testing with junit or a junit extension? I've
> looked at JUnitPerf and I don't think it has the functionality I need. I'd like
> to record the time taken to execute individual junit tests. The idea is that it
> should then be possible identify when code changes occurred that caused a
> significant drop in performance.
>
> thanks
> Nathan

You could probably do this if you wrote a custom TestRunner.

If you know Aspect-Oriented Programming, this also seems like a good use for it.
It would be fairly simple to write an aspect which reported elapsed execution
time on a per-test-method level. You could write the data on all tests for each
run to a CSV file, for example. Then you could use a spreadsheet or other tool
to perform trend analysis on the collected data over time.
